body:
Added negative tests around the info call if backups don't exist.
Moved the classes to common where the classes for the node exist.
Added a bunch of docs on the classes themselves.
Great contribution. is it possible to remove the dependency on the os stdlib?
Oh, and please can you develop and add some tests for this as well. We don't have CI tests for Windows with Travis CI so unittests as a minimum.
Thanks for your contribution @vdloo this looks great. :+1:
Merged :+1:
the additional changes look great. thanks @jadunham1 merging.
@tonybaloney, @vdloo

Can do! I just added in some unit tests, got rid of the os and sys dependencies, reformatted according style guide a bit better, and rebased the pull request. Let me know if there's any other comments, I'm happy to make changes.
I'd vote for moving to requests.  Let libcloud focus on the multi-cloud aspect and let requests handle the http heavy lifting.  We'd have to drop Python 2.5 support, but I think that's ok.
this is a good addition to the base class. I agree with you @allardhoeve it is a good design. :+1:

It's also worth noting that this is a backward incompatible change for any place which doesn't use keyword arguments so we need to make sure it doesn't break any of the existing drivers and document it in the upgrade notes.
I could put the new keyword after the `extra=None`, that way it breaks nothing. But yes, it should be in the Changelog
I agree, this is better than using the driver and passing the node object in  :+1:
Passed. Merging
@Kami @erjohnso @jcsalterego @runseb @allardhoeve - this is an important one. Are you happy with the way this works?
:+1: LGTM
need to investigate the use of basestring. the libcloud one isn't a superclass of unicode and str like it is in the std library. which is annoying. @Kami is that on purpose?
I'm also not a huge fan as I have to make sure it isn't unicode when going in.  It was what we were using as conventions before so I kept with it as the code was this way.
Looks simple enough to me.
Okey, I changed the field name to `created_at` and the order of the named arguments. If everyone is on board, I'd like to commit this and revert #697.
:+1: from me
@vdloo
LGTM @tonybaloney. Nice clean up!
Hi. Changes look good. So the feature in GCE is beta? Any idea when it will be completed? @erjohnso

The feature is already in beta, but our plan for releasing it into the v1 API includes making third party client updates. You can view the documentation for a new "getFromFamily" API endpoint here: https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/beta/images/getFromFamily

Image publishers need to create new images with the family property set before the feature will be generally useful. In order to begin the transition, we are making API client updates that enable using the feature during image creation.
Understood. Wouldn't want to introduce a chicken & egg then. Changes LGTM :+1:
The tests are looking great now @jadunham1
@onecloudportal @marcydoty @jvitorsf please see previous comment, if you can please make the changes I'd be happy to merge.
Hi @juanfont how did you get on with the tests? Would be good to get this closed off since you've already done most of the hard work!
@Kami what are we doing with this?
we don't support py 2.5 anymore @jimbobhickville so thats ok.

I say ditch it (I will close the PR).

I haven't found a way to make it work across all the supported Python versions and we should also encourage people to use language agnostic serialization / de-serialization protocols / formats (e.g. JSON).

If needed, we can also add some helper methods for that (e.g. to_dict and from_dict).

So perhaps we should add some documentation on that (how to handle serialization / de-serialization - ideally use something like JSON, or even better, just serialize object IDs and always retrieve objects when you need to manipulate them - this way you won't have out of date and consistency issues).

Closing.

See the comment above.

Yay, removing code is always great (less stuff to maintainer, less surface area for bugs, etc.) :P

LGTM
@tonybaloney sorry about the delay. Hope it is enough :)
Great! thanks @juanfont :+1:
Thanks @juanfont LGTM

Slightly confused, I see some other changes, but no basestring related changes.

Am I missing something? :)
Sorry for the delay and thanks for the contribution.
I tried to make some basestring changes, then broke a whole bunch of unit tests. I should have closed this PR.
@jadunham1 this def needs tests against both MCP 1 and MCP 2 locations, I don't know if the response formats are the same.
Disk looks the same from both MCP1/2, added the test.

@jshridha Thanks.

Next time please ping us when you push updates since we don't get notified when you push new changes :)

I've pushed some minor fixes / improvements and merged the patch into trunk (I also verified the patch is working).

Thanks!

Thanks.

The changes look good to me, but I will wait for @tonybaloney.
Yeah, I imagine changing / fixing the basestring stuff will be quite painful... :/
Thanks @jetbird for the PR. Let me know when this is completed. Also if you install flake8 locally you can run the code checks to pass the failing lint build job in travis.
@Kami Will do, I didn't realize that new pushes didn't result in notifications. Also, thanks for the great review!

It appears that this driver never worked - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35553386/apache-libcloud-dns-and-godaddy-name-or-service-not-known

I pushed a fix in a3ba6a4751623224f16175df9175ec06b29cdc1a

@tonybaloney @Kami   I think we have a problem in implementing the def create_record(self, name, zone, type, data, extra=None) method. From what I understand when reading the API, the provider does not support adding a name for the new record.

Under Records take a look on the PUT method https://ns1.com/api/

First thanks for the contribution! We will look into it as soon as possible.

In the mean time, since this is a larger contribution, please make sure you file an ICLA with Apache - https://libcloud.readthedocs.org/en/latest/development.html#contributing-bigger-changes and please let us know when you have done so.
Thanks for this @illfelder! Please squash into a single commit and then I'll merge it in.
Updated to be a single commit.

Fooey. I just merged (commit 7013b6a190c0017ab13e0cea95a36eaeceb2abb2), but forgot to update the commit message so it would auto-close this PR.

Please manually close when you confirm the change is merged to trunk.

Thanks again Max!
Confirmed! Thanks!

Add some extra states to the list (optional). But otherwise @jadunham1 
![thumbs up](http://media3.giphy.com/media/FX3OLJAUhOZNK/giphy.gif)
@Kami, you are right. Coding it now.

As I can't test all of these in what they look like (do they have workflows associated ect?) I'd rather push as is and people can add to define states.  Things like failed adds I'm not sure I can simulate correctly.
We're definitely in a better position to react to new states ect in this model.
@tonybaloney  It is finished man. Please take a look at the code.

@Kami I have signed icla and email the pdf to secretary@apache.org.
BTW, I fixed the failed test, but FORCE pushed it to my fork branch. How to trigger the ci to test it again?

@erjohnso @Kami could you PTAL at this. We need to pull a fix in for this internally at Google.
@tonybaloney I managed to flake8 the code.
All tests pass Travis-CI except one. Error message is related to the non-configuration of lint for Python 2.7. Is there something I can do on this?

Good catch, thanks.

I did at some test cases for this, but looks like I missed this edge case :( I will merge this into trunk and also add a test case for this.

Thanks again.

Added a test case (f61f3cfded51077ed3b4802b1675ac7937c7d5c7) and merged patch into trunk.

Thanks.

I've added some comments. Overall, very nice work :+1: 

After you look into / address those comments, could you please also add some documentation for those drivers?

Yeah, you need to de-indent the `})` line.

``` python
        for disk in findall(element, 'disk', TYPES_URN):
            extra['disks'].append({
                'scsiId': int(disk.get('scsiId')),
                'speed': disk.get('speed'),
                'id': disk.get('id'),
                'size': int(disk.get('sizeGb'))
            })
```

It also wouldn't hurt if you split this functionality into a separate `_to_disk(self, data)` method, similar as we do in other places.
And of course, thanks for the contribution :)
thanks Kami, let's do that
ok, now seems to be ok - thanks for the consideration of this PR
Agreed. :+1:

@jetbird Nice work so far :+1: 

The next step would be adding some tests and documentation :)

As a side note, this has been left in the _to_node() function for the time being. This is because disks are natural attributes of the get_node(). Like this was done for the CPU, maybe one day we will find a good reason to enrich the service and to better justify another function, a separate class, etc.

hey @bernard357 great to see some contrib back. Can you provide a test to check the values of the disk extra parameter please? You can copy the method pattern here- https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/test/compute/test_dimensiondata.py#L94 the existing fixtures have the disks in them
Please ignore the pull request..
Fixed conflicts and merged.
Thanks Anthony for your encouragements. Libcloud tests are new to me, so please allow me to dive into these first. Keep posted...

Anthony, it is great that you already worked on _to_disk(), DimensionDataServerDisk, etc. For some reason this has not reached my workstation on git pull some days ago. So, at the end of the day, this PR is completely useless and should be dropped. Instead, I will change the code in plumbery to align with your contribution. Also, I may produce additional tests as suggested, if this can turn me to a better padawan. Let the Open Force be with us :-)
Thanks for the contribution.
Test case for `list_records` method which returns a MX record would also be nice :)
This test improvement is enough. I think somehow the PR code got merged already, so the disk support is already in the driver.,
@jadunham1 did the work for you @bernard357 his PR has already been merged. I suggest you close this one https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/708

Pushed some fixes and improvements (1d0b2eeeb710ecbf3f65a34df3c38170a78a5216, 29296923046b4cecea200ee5aa3fb9e51f20ce77), added a test case (bd3c1f044cb59333e3c6bd20cc6bff4db1428316) and merged changes into trunk.

Thanks!
:+1: verified
@Kami It's my fault. I didn't fill the 'notify project' field. I will re-sign the ICLA.
LGTM :+1:
@Kami @tonybaloney  guys did you find some time to check the tests?

@samsong8610 Sorry for the delay, I was traveling.

I will look into reviewing it again and merging it ASAP (tomorrow).

Thanks.

Besides the `type` thing, LGTM.

/cc @tonybaloney

I went ahead and merged changes into trunk.

Thanks again for this very complete and high-quality contribution!
Glad to help the libcloud. Thanks for your review.
@jadunham1 yeah the parameter should be removed completely, it isn't required
